title: Le mini hoop
description: Le mini hoop is a mini basketball hoop with an automatic return system powered by 600 rpm motor.
This was my team project from my mechanical design class, we set out to reduce the friction of having to pick up the basketball after every shot.
The frame was laser cut with acrylic, the ramp was a laser cut out of wood with a living hinge design (to flex as a ramp), and the flywheels & gears were 3D printed with PLA.
When fully spun, the flywheels can launch the ball to the person's chest up to ~10 feet.

We ran into some roadblocks. We wanted to use a motion sensor to turn on the motor when the ball was in the funnel, but it took too long for the flywheels to spin up. So the motor was controlled with an on/off switch. Also, we didn't plan out fully how the electrical components would fit in the assembly, so there was a bit of a mess with wires in the end product.

title: Fusion Copilot (CAD+AI)
description: Fusion Copilot is a Fusion add-in where users can enter a query for what they want to build, and the add-in will make the design for them
Currently, the add-in sends a request to a ChatGPT model that has been tuned to use the Fusion python API and receives executable Fusion API code back. The add-in then executes the code in Fusion.
Right now, there is a limitation in how complex the designs can be.
You can check out the demo to see its current state.

title: Ansys Codefest
description: I participated in the 2024 Ansys Codefest where teams had 8 hours to optimize the cost of a dwarven bridge (with 95 nodes).
To minimize cost, I sorted the beams by the least stress, and programmatically simulated different materials and cross-sections corresponding to each beams' stress.
The idea was that we would use cheaper materials & cross-sections until all the beams are near their yield stress.
My team was able to reduce the cost of the bridge by 50%
This project used PyAnsys API and simulation tools.

title: RealFlight Simulations
description: I added a model of my project team's drone into RealFlight Evolution. I used Blender to abstract our drone's faces so it could be imported into RealFlight. I had to map the geometry and physics to RealFlight, so things like the drone's center of mass and thrust would be realistic.
My project team is making a 300mph+ drone, so this accurate RealFlight model was important for the CS team to integrate software in the loop tests using INAV.

title: Road Rage (CV Game)
description: This was my team's entry for the 2025 BigRedHacks Hackathon.
It uses your laptop camera to track your hands via Mediapipe and OpenCV. The game is entirely rendered in ThreeJS.
It features a player car, coins to be collected, NPC cars that can be crashed into, and a procedurally generated road.
Road Rage won in the design track category for this hackathon

title: BigRedHacks Hackathon
description: This app (Nocturne) was created for the Big Red Hacks 2024 Hackathon. It lets users pick a mood and type their feelings to generate a song that adapts to their emotions.
My team won 2nd place for the overall Hackathon of best fitting the theme of Lifestyle. We all got nice pairs of beats headphones as our prize.
I used React Native + Expo + Typescript, and my team used a Flask Backend.

title: RCareWorld Hackathon
description: Vividly was created for the RCareWorld 2024 Hackathon. It helps people with alzheimers remember important events in their life by saving important events and images. The app also lets users AI generate a story of a person's life based on the events they have saved.
My team won 1st place for the Hackathon track of Inclusive Solutions to Existing Systems. We received a $500 prize.
I used React Native + Expo + Typescript, and the backend was with Flask.

title: 2500words Chrome Extension
description: 2500words allows you to refine your vocabulary in a foreign language. It adds an option on right click to "Add {word} to 2500words." Doing so creates an immediate translation on the page. The word will also be saved for review which can be accessed by clicking on the extension icon.
The translations are made with Google Translate's API and your words are stored locally.
Made with pure JS / HTML / CSS

title: Debate Flow Website
description: I made this website after judging debate tournaments for a couple years and realized it was very annoying to keep track of my flows. I also wanted a better way to make flows and be able to transition to the aff/neg flow quickly. So I added keyboard shortcuts to make it easier to switch between flows.
The stack is React + NextJS + Typescript + TailwindCSS
